Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: TDM solar cells: Bifacial III-V nanowire array on silicon tandem solar cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Non-Technical:
Conventional state-of-the-art tandem junction photovoltaic solar cells, composed of multiple sub-cells of III-V compound semiconductors, are capable of converting incident radiation from the Sun to electricity with greater efficiency than all other types of solar cells. The high performance of these devices is enabled in part due to the use of high quality monocrystalline III-V materials and in part due to the coupling of multiple sub-cells that collectively allow for absorption of a broadband solar spectral range. However, the materials and manufacturing costs required for the development of III-V tandem junction devices is prohibitively high for use in wide-scale terrestrial consumer applications. As a consequence, the world's highest performance solar cells are limited to use in niche markets such as terrestrial high concentration and space power applications. A high-risk, high-payoff exploratory research path is proposed here that aims to provide an unconventional, yet potentially transformative nanotechnology-enabled solution to the above consumer market penetration challenges faced by state-of-the-art tandem junction solar cells. The project aims to dramatically reduce manufacturing costs by monolithically integrating III-V sub-cell composed of vertical nanowire arrays to a central silicon sub-cell, thereby simultaneously eliminating the primary III-V substrate cost-driver while cutting III-V crystal growth volumes by up to 95% compared to conventional technologies. The broader significance of this EAGER project lies in the potential realization of a low-cost and high-efficiency renewable energy innovation that provides greater national energy independence and clean power. This research also impacts and advances fundamental knowledge in science and engineering in the fields of physics, nanomaterials growth and characterization, nanoelectronics, and optoelectronics. Immediate anticipated societal impacts include outreach activities that promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics concepts to the general public, training new members of a highly-skilled workforce, and direct inclusion of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students from under-represented communities.

Technical:
The technical approach of this EAGER project relies on selective-area heteroepitaxy of a GaAsP (1.75 eV) nanowire array on the top surface of a thinned Si (1.1 eV) sub-cell by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition. A bifacial, three dissimilar materials, tandem junction device is formed via monolithic integration of a back-side InGaAs (0.5 eV) nanowire array. The vertical nanowires comprising the top- and back-surface arrays will contain radially-segmented p-i-n junctions and will be serially connected to the central Si sub-cell via epitaxial tunnel junctions. This design enables absorption of broadband incident solar energy as well as albedo radiation. Standard lattice-matching constraints are overcome via strain relaxation along nanowire free surfaces. Therefore, ideal spectral matching is realized without a need for graded buffer layers or dislocation mediation strategies. Use of vertical nanowire arrays with coaxial p-i-n junction geometries permits key advantages, including near-unity absorption of solar irradiance at normal and tilted incidence without the use of anti-reflection coatings, decoupling of photon absorption and carrier collection directions, and dramatic reduction of 95% in epitaxial volumes. Rigorous modeling of device parameters will be iteratively coupled with extensive materials characterization and property correlation experiments for optimization of III-V sub-cell structure on the single nanowire and ensemble array levels. The ultimate target of this work is demonstration of a functional bifacial, three dissimilar materials, nanowire-based tandem junction solar cell with one Sun power conversion efficiency of 30% or better.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to conduct exploratory research on the monolithic integration of two dissimilar materials systems using cost-effective synthesis methods that enable novel and high power conversion efficiency photovoltaic solar cell device architectures. Through a combination of theoretical and experimental approaches, Rochester Institute of Technology investigated the development of a transformative bifacial tandem-junction solar cell design comprised of two dissimilar III-V semiconductor nanowire arrays, serially connected to a central Si sub-cell. This design enables broadband absorption from 0.5 eV to 1.75 eV, as well as albedo radiation. Novel III-V nanowire crystal growth methods, solar cell device structures, and fabrication methods, as well as advanced computational approaches, were explored in a multidisciplinary research effort intended to advance knowledge and understanding in the field of high-efficiency, third-generation photovoltaics.

Central to this project was the growth and characterization of III-V semiconductor nanowire arrays on Si. In contrast to conventional thin film device architectures, nanowires overcome the technical challenge of lattice-matching through relief of strain along their free surfaces. This enables direct integration of dissimilar photovoltaic materials without formation of detrimental threading dislocations. Using nanowire geometries, ideal spectral matching can realized without a need for graded buffer layers or dislocation mitigation strategies. Additionally, near unity absorption of solar irradiance is enabled without anti-reflection coatings, while using only a small fraction of the epitaxial volume of standard planar solar cell designs.

In this work, wafer-scale crystal growth of III-V nanowire arrays by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition was carried out on Si sub-cells through the exploration of three distinct catalyst-free epitaxial synthesis modes. Firstly, growth of GaAsP nanowire arrays was realized by exploiting the selective-area epitaxy growth mode. Site-specific nanowire growth was enabled by wafer-scale displacement Talbot lithography to overcome low-throughput and high-cost challenges associated with electron-beam lithography pattering, and to overcome the uniformity challenges associated with nanosphere lithography approaches. Secondly, growth of InAsP and InAlAs nanowire arrays on graphene-coated Si wafers was realized via the van der Waals epitaxial self-assembly method. Lastly, growth of InAsP nanowire arrays was realized on Si sub-cells using a novel site-selective self-assembly or pseudo-selective-area epitaxy technique. In this approach, conventional and low-cost photolithography was used to limit nucleation sites to 500 nm-diameter windows on the substrate surface, along which strain-limited self-assembly of ~100 nm-diameter nanowires occurred.

A new fabrication process was developed through which nanowire arrays were delaminated from the growth surface, enabling fabrication of independent flexible devices and subsequent reuse of the original Si substrate and masking template for regrowth of new generations of III-V nanowire arrays. Using this approach, intermediate substrate restoration processes were eliminated from the conventional substrate reuse process, leading to a dramatic reduction in manufacturing cost of III-V photovoltaic devices. Proof-of-concept solar cells composed of radial p-i-n junction GaAsP nanowire arrays on Si, as well as coaxially heterostructured p-GaAsP/n-GaP core/shell nanowire arrays on Si, were fabricated that demonstrated the viability of the novel crystal growth protocols. Flexible nanowire-based InAsP devices were also demonstrated and the Si substrate reuse process was successful applied for regrowth of both GaAsP and InAsP nanowire arrays.

With regards to the theoretical aspects of the project, a fully integrated RSoft and Sentaurus co-simulation utility was successfully demonstrated for periodic nanowire systems. The co-simulation approach was applied to optimize the electrical performance of both high-energy and low-energy nanowire-based sub-cells. Analysis of the GaAsP nanowire junction geometry revealed that the height of the axial emitter component must be limited to 50 nm in order to ensure optimal performance. An efficiency of 16.5% was achieved for a radial p-i-n junction GaAsP nanowire solar cell, assuming a surface recombination velocity value of 1300 cm/s. The possibility of a heterojunction GaAsP-GaP core-shell design for increased open-circuit voltage was shown to be viable due to the reduction of the emitter bulk dark current contribution to the total losses.  Applied to the low-energy back-surface sub-cell, our model revealed that the generated current density of InAsP nanowire arrays encapsulated in a polymer medium is strongly enhanced with the use of concave back-surface reflectors. A ~4 mA/cm2 increase in current density was realized for 400 nm-diameter nanowires with spacing of 900 nm, in comparison to arrays without concave back surface reflectors. An enhancement of ~1.3 mA/cm2 was also realized when concave reflectors were used in comparison to planar back-surface reflectors.

This work broadly impacts society by providing new routes toward the simultaneous realization of low-cost and high-efficiency renewable solar energy. This research project has generated new members of a highly skilled workforce, through education and training provided to graduate and postdoctoral researchers in the technologically relevant fields of materials science, physics, and electrical engineering. Outreach activities that incorporated aspects of this work have impacted the Rochester, NY community by introducing STEM-related concepts to the general public, particularly to high school students in underrepresented communities.
